Lord, ſir, what would you have had me do? I'm ſure I made the beſt gueſs I could,
and would have given the man any thing in the world had I only known that he wanted nothing.

sp.speaker: MOD.
sp.p: Madam, madam, you have committed the fault—you muſt repair it. Go this moment to my ſiſter's, entreat her to intercede for us with Mr. Rivers, and either bring home his pardon or never hope for mine. Exit,

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: Yes, I muſt go. Slip-ſlop, my cloak!—Such a princely fortune loſt!—I remember now to have heard of Mortimer's immenſe wealth; and perhaps at the very moment he pleaded for half-a-crown, his pockets were ſtuffed with pearls and diamonds; and I warrant his odious black ſcratch periwig had been papilloted with bank-notes!—Oh! I could go diſtracted. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE I.—Mrs. ORMOND'S.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORMOND.
sp.p: MISS Mandeville's manners coarſe, and her perſon diſagreeable?

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Upon my word I thought ſo; but I've been ſo long abſent from the faſhionable circles, that poſſibly ſhe may be the general taſte; I'm only certain that ſhe's not at all to mine.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: And when you ſpoke of her return to India....

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Oh! ſhe could not endure the very mention of it. I was really afraid ſhe'd have gone into hyſterics.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: Strange! But, however, I'll aſcertain the fact to-morrow, and this myſtery ſhall be explained.

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: 'Till then let the matter reſt.—And now, my dear Emily... [A knocking without.] Hey! what can be the meaning of that thundering rap?

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Lady Clara Modiſh.

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Lady Clara Devil! and I'd rather meet the latter. Which way is ſhe coming up?

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: This way. Exit.

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Then I'll go down the other.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: Oh! pray ſtay.

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: No, no; I'm not yet cool enough to conceal from the woman how heartily I deſpiſe her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: Yet perhaps her neglect of you...

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: I gueſſ what you would ſay, my good Emily. A moment of ill humour, a diſh of tea too ſtrong, a bad run of luck laſt night, the indiſposition of her lap-dog, or any other fine-lady-like affliction, might occaſion her indifference to my diſtreſs—but that ſhe could ſee the infant graces of your child without intereſt, that ſhe could ſuffer without compaſſion an heart like yours to languiſh in poverty, betrays an inſenſibility which I never can forgive. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: You muſt though, my dear ſir, or your heart is compoſed of tougher materials than I imagine. Yes, yes, Rivers and my brother muſt be friends, and probably that brings Lady Clara hither.—So, here ſhe comes!

div.stage: Servant ſhews in Lady Clara, and exit.

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: My dear Mrs. Ormond, I've juſt hurried hither for one inſtant!—Why, they tell me you've been indiſpoſed. You look charmingly, however: But, you cruel creature, why did not you let me know you were ill?

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: Knowing your exquiſite ſenſibility, Lady Clara, ſurely it had been barbarous in me to torture your nerves by a recital of my ſufferings.
Oh! fye, fye! when the delicate attentions of friendſhip can alleviate....I proteſt, Mrs. Ormond, you've got a mighty pretty houſe here.
Tolerable. Mr. Rivers inſiſted upon my removing hither immediately, and therefore things are not quite....

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p:
Mr. Rivers! Dear, that puts me in mind—I want to talk to you about him. Do
you know, he put the drolleſt trick upon me this morning!

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: [archly.] So he did upon me; but you were too cunning for him: I, poor innocent, was completely the dupe of his feigned diſtreſſes; but upon you, he tells me, they made not the ſlighteſt impreſſion.

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! no more they did—Ha, ha, ha!— [Aſide] Spiteful thing, how I hate her!—But, my dear Mrs. Ormond, you...you relieved him then....

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: Oh! the relief in my power to afford him was very moderate; and in truth our exchange of preſents bore no proportion to one another. I had nothing to beſtow on him but a very trifle and a diſh of tea, and he repaid me with notes of not leſs than a thouſand pounds.

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: Mercy on me! a thouſand pounds for a diſh of tea? How unlucky it was that I had juſt ſent away the chocolateThis trait is borrowed from Mercier's "Habitant de la Guadaloupe."!

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: Then he has ſuch plans for equipages, diamonds, and eſtates....It would quite fatigue you, Lady Clara, only to hear the liſt.

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: Oh! I ſhall faint preſently! [aſide.] —But I hope the dear beggar thinks this trick of his as entertaining as you and I do?

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: I am afraid he takes the affair a little more ſeriouſly.

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: But ſurely, my dear creature, you can explain to him....

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p:
Believe me, Lady Clara, however great may be my cauſe of complaint, my brother's intereſt will never ceaſe to be mine; and
if my interference can poſſibly produce a reconciliation....

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: You will uſe it? Let me die now if that isn't being extremely kind; but indeed I always ſaid you had one of the beſt hearts in the world. And ſuppoſe now, to loſe no time, you were to bring Mr. Rivers to my houſe tonight?

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: To-night? Why really....my mourning....

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: Oh! as to your mourning, you know you'll be conſidered as at home; for, is not my houſe, is not every thing I poſſeſs, as much yours as my own?

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: You're too kind, Lady Clara; indeed you're too kind!

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: Not at all! oh dear, not at all! I ſhall expect you then, and pray bring Mr. Rivers.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: I'll do my beſt; but in truth I doubt my being able to prevail on him, unleſs you can make uſe of Falſtaff's excuſe, and proteſt ſolemnly that you knew him all the while: however, if he ſhould not come, depend upon it's not being a fault of mine.

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: Well now, that's a dear creature; and I hope to Heaven you may ſuceeed! Yet ſhould your endeavours to appeaſe Mr. Rivers prove fruitleſs, I ſhall conſole myſelf with the reflection that at leaſt my dear ſiſter enjoys thoſe advantages of which, by imprudence, I have deprived myſelf.— [Aſide] Oh! I could tear her eyes out! Exit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! I ſuſpect Lady Clara leaves me not too well pleaſed with her viſit.—So, here comes Mr. Rivers!

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: So, Emily, your viſitor is gone; and now let me know what brought her hither.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: Can you ſeriouſly aſk that queſtion?

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Why I believe I could gueſs—your brother no doubt—

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: Even ſo. Lady Clara's errand was to expreſs her contrition for this morning's adventure with all poſſible humility, and requeſt your preſence at her houſe to-night for the expreſs purpoſe of receiving her huſband's apologies and her own.

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Aye? Well! well! I'm glad to hear it—I'll go—

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: Will you?

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Aye; and ſo ſhall you.—I intend to take the liberty of tormenting her Ladyſhip—and ſhe'll not be the worſe for a little wholeſome mortification—

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: Nay, that is a fact which I cannot take upon me to deny.

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p:
And now for the ſcene of action; where you ſhall ſee crowds of coxcombs, and legions of coquettes at my coming, all "diſſolve,
And like the baſeleſs fabric of a viſion
Leave not one fop behind."

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: You've a ſecret then for killing inſects, I preſume?

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: No, only for diſperſing them, and my taliſman conſiſts in pronouncing that ſingle cabaliſtical word "Diſtreſs;" away they go; for in fact, my dear Emily, a faſhionable friend is an abſolute bird of paſſage,—

q.l: Which here, while Summer reigns, enjoys the day,
Wings the • arm gale, and courts the kindly ray:
But ſoon as Winter lours, and ſtorms ariſe,
To brighter ſcenes the airy wanderer flies,
Where breathe leſs boiſterous winds, where ſmile leſs clouded ſkies.

sp.speaker: Lord LIST.
sp.p: The writ was executed, you ſay?

sp.speaker: FRIP.
sp.p: Oui, my lor; et Le Colonel Beauchamp, be tres bien lock up chez cet honnête, Monſieur Touchit!

sp.speaker: Lord LIST.
sp.p: Good! but unluckily Beauchamp has friends, who wont leave him there long.—Now could I find ſome laſting means of revenging myſelf on the puppy....What ſay you, monſieur?

sp.speaker: FRIP.
sp.p: Mais voyons, my lor, voyons! Suppoſe—ſuppoſe you carry off Mademoiſelle Mandeville?

sp.speaker: Lord LIST.
sp.p: I carry her off?—Why ſhould I take the trouble?

sp.speaker: FRIP.
sp.p: Mon dieu! you not ſee?—Beauchamp love mademoiſelle à la folie; but ven all of von ſudden ſhe diſappear, he vil ſwear, vil cry, vil go diſtract! and ven Mademoiſelle Mandeville been two tree day wid your lorſhip, ſerviteur à la reputation de Mademoiſelle Mandeville.

sp.speaker: Lord LIST.
sp.p: Um! the idea would be tolerable if it were not that afterwards Beauchamp might take it into his head to cut my throat.—Now that I ſhouldn't like, becauſe you know it would dirty my neckloth.

sp.speaker: FRIP.
sp.p: Ma foi, mi lor, en verite! dat it voud! mais l'Italie, mi lor? vy you not enlever la petite....

sp.speaker: Lord LIST.
sp.p: Right, right.—But then how to get hold of her, monſieur?

sp.speaker: FRIP.
sp.p: Oh c'eſt bien facile! I go vid a chair to Lady Clara's, and as mademoiſelle go in, or as ſhe come out, I vip her into de ſedan, de chair-men vip her up, your lorſhip vip her away; et voila' qu'elle eſt priſe, pardi!

sp.speaker: Lord LIST.
sp.p: Um, could this be done quietly, and in a proper way....for a buſtle always bores me, 'pon my ſoul!

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: How, in cloſe conſultation, my Lord? Perhaps I intrude.

sp.speaker: Lord LIST.
sp.p: Oh! by no means; I've a little buſineſs indeed, which....

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: A ſecret?

sp.speaker: Lord LIST.
sp.p: Um! you might ſerve me in it, if it were not—

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: My dear lord, too happy if—

sp.speaker: Lord LIST.
sp.p: And you'll be ſilent?

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: As a conceal'd author, whoſe comedy has juſt been damn'd. I give you my word! and now—

sp.speaker: Lord LIST.
sp.p: You muſt know, then, I'm on the point of eloping with a certain young lady....

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: You? Good heavens! how can you take ſo much trouble! and have you a chaiſe-and-four ready?

sp.speaker: Lord LIST.
sp.p: No, but I ſhall order my ſedan chair to be prepared immediately.

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: A ſedan? 'Faith that's new!—Well, you'll order your chair to Gretna Green, I hope?

sp.speaker: Lord LIST.
sp.p:
Oh! you miſtake the buſineſs: the lady in queſtion is in love with a fellow, who bores
me intolerably; and I carry off his miſtreſs, merely for the ſake of plaguing him.

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: Merely for the ſake of plaguing him!

sp.speaker: Lord LIST.
sp.p: Nothing elſe, 'pon my ſoul! The idea's good, an't it?

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: Good? it's excellent!

sp.speaker: Lord LIST.
sp.p: Now the only difficulty is, how to entice her to the ſpot where my ſervants will be waiting for her; and if any friend—

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: Entice her!—then ſhe's not appris'd of the honour intended her by your lordſhip?

sp.speaker: Lord LIST.
sp.p: Has'nt the moſt diſtant idea of it; and, in fact, hates me like the devil.

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: Zounds! my lord, but that makes the joke a great deal better!—And could you poſſibly doubt my aſſiſting ſo honourable a deſign?—

sp.speaker: Lord LIST.
sp.p: Why, to tell you the truth, (but remember your promiſe of ſecrecy) the lady is no other than Miſs Mandeville; and as you are Beauchamp's friend—

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: Pſhaw! what does that ſignify?—Isn't he a commoner, an't you a peer? Isn't he poor, an't you rich? Isn't he an old friend, an't you a new acquaintance? And can you doubt which of the two I ſhould prefer ſerving?—My dear lord, pray judge a little more of me by yourſelf!

sp.speaker: Lord LIST.
sp.p: [aſide.] A ſenſible fellow, 'pon my ſoul!—You'll undertake then to—

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: And think myſelf too happy in being of uſe to you, only let your chair and ſervants be ready—

sp.speaker: Lord LIST.
sp.p:
Oh! monſieur ſhall take care of that.—Friponeau, attend this gentleman, conduct Miſs Mandeville hither, and when ſhe arrives wake me. [Exit FRIPONEAU] Good evening, Walſingham.
'Pon my ſoul extremely obliged to you; am indeed....a....a....a....'pon my ſoul! Exit.

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: Go thy ways, thou prince of puppies! But 'tis well that this fellow has made me his confident, for the conſequences of his ſcheme might have been very unpleaſant to Zorayda; but now to mar it, and, if poſſible, get him into a ſcrape, of which at preſent he little dreams. The ſcoundrel!—but alas! there are but too many in the world, who, like him, would ſoon make themſelves villains, if nature hadn't kindly prevented it by making them fools.

div.head: SCENE III.—An anti-chamber at Lady Clara's.
div.stage: Company croſs the Stage. Servants paſs with refreſhments.
Enter Miſs CHATTERALL and Mrs. BLAB-ALL.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BLAB.
sp.p: Nay, my ſoul, if this letter be authentic, Lady Clara muſt give up Miſs Mandeville, or my acquaintance, I'll aſſure you!

sp.speaker: Miſs CHAT.
sp.p: Oh dear! My dear, as to that, I ſhall viſit Lady Clara no more at any rate, unleſs indeed ſhe gives a maſquerade; and then you know nobody need know whether one viſits her or not.—But accept a favour from her bare-faced!—Lord, my love, I bluſh at the very thought! Oh 'tis a ſad family!

sp.speaker: Mrs. BLAB.
sp.p: Shocking, my dear!

sp.speaker: Miſs CHAT.
sp.p:
True, my life; only conceive! Beauchamp in gaol, Mrs. Ormond intriguing with him, Miſs Mandeville eloped, and Lady Clara giving entertainments when her huſband's going
to be arreſted, and her brother's at the point of death.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BLAB.
sp.p: Oh! fye, fye, fye! I proteſt I'm quite ſhocked.

sp.speaker: M • ſs CHAT.
sp.p: Shocked, my dear? ſo am I, an't I?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BLAB.
sp.p: But Lord Liſtleſs dying? I never heard of that before.

sp.speaker: Miſs CHAT.
sp.p: No? Dear, I thought every body had heard that Lord Liſtleſs having diſcovered an intrigue between Beauchamp and Mrs. Ormond with whom he was himſelf on certain terms....You underſtand me, my dear?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BLAB.
sp.p: Oh Lord! yes my dear to be ſure I do; well, my love, and ſo—

sp.speaker: Miſs. CHAT.
sp.p: Well, and ſo, my life, my Lord was ſo ſevere in his obſervations, that at length Beauchamp got into a terrible rage, rapped out three great oaths that he'd be the death of him, ſeized a blunderbuſs (which happened to be upon the breakfaſt table) ſhot his lordſhip through the body, and the Colonel and his enamorata immediately made off for France, with the intention of offering their ſervices to the triumvirate. How odd! an't it?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BLAB.
sp.p: Odd indeed!—But lord! my life, how unlucky it was that Mrs. Ormond ſhould happen to have a blunderbuſs lying on her breakfaſt table?

sp.speaker: Miſs CHAT.
sp.p: Extremely unlucky indeed, my dear. But come let us in, and if Miſs Mandeville ſhews her face to night, I ſhall tell Lady Clara what I think of her very plainly! for after all, my dear, to own a truth, the greateſt advantage I ever could find in walking ſtraight myſelf in the path of virtue, was the privilege of inſulting thoſe who ſtep a little on one ſide. Come, my dear! Exeunt.

div.stage: [As they go off, enter WALSINGHAM and FRIPONEAU.]

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: Do you ſee her? There ſhe goes!

sp.speaker: FRIP.
sp.p: Vid de ſcarlet plume?

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p:
The ſame: wait at the great entrance till I entice her to the door, then convey her to your maſter with all ſpeed.
Exit Friponeau.

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: Hiſt, hiſt, Miſs Chatterall!

sp.speaker: Miſs CHAT.
sp.p: Mr. Walſingham, didn't you—

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: Huſh! ſpeak ſoftly! My dear young lady, I've juſt diſcovered the moſt abominable deſign, the moſt atrocious plot!

sp.speaker: Miſs CHAT.
sp.p: Eh! what? againſt me?

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: Againſt you!

sp.speaker: Miſs CHAT.
sp.p: Oh! Goodneſs defend me!

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: And am come to caution you not to venture near the great entrance without ſufficient protection.

sp.speaker: Miſs CHAT.
sp.p: Dear me! and why?

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: The infamous agents of a certain nobleman are waiting there for the expreſs purpoſe of carrying you off.

sp.speaker: Miſs CHAT.
sp.p: Lord bleſs me!

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: And though I well know your virtue to be proof againſt either force or artifice—

sp.speaker: Miſs CHAT.
sp.p: Undoubtedly!

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: Yet, as this affair would make ſuch a diſturbance—

sp.speaker: Miſs CHAT.
sp.p: Terrible!

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: Would get into all the newſpapers—

sp.speaker: Miſs CHAT.
sp.p: Odious!

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: And render you the ſubject of general animadverſion.....

sp.speaker: Miſs CHAT.
sp.p: Execrable!

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: The conſequences would be, that either your friends would fight a duel on your account—

sp.speaker: Miſs CHAT.
sp.p: Tremendous!

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: Or you quiet the buſineſs by a marriage with his Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Miſs CHAT.
sp.p: Charming—Monſtrous I mean!

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: The beſt thing you can do, therefore, is to ſend for a guard—

sp.speaker: Miſs CHAT.
sp.p: I'll do it inſtantly—

sp.speaker: WAL
sp.p: Return home under its protection—

sp.speaker: Miſs CHAT.
sp.p: With the utmoſt diligence—

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: And above all, take care not to approach the great entrance.

sp.speaker: Miſs CHAT.
sp.p: I approach it!—Oh Mr. Walſingham! I'd rather die than advance a ſingle ſtep towards it: Good evening, and a thouſand thanks!

div.stage: [A pauſe, after which Miſs Chatterall puts in her head, looks round cautiouſly, then hurries acroſs the ſtage, and exit.]

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: So my plot has taken effect. Now if her friends can but perſuade Lord Liſtleſs to repair her injuries by marriage, (and I know he has no great fondneſs for fighting,) the breed will be excellent, and I ſhall immediately put in my claim for a puppy!

div.stage: Enter ZORAYDA (in an Evening Dreſs) as from the Aſſembly Room.

sp.speaker: WALS.
sp.p: What, Miſs Mandeville, retiring ſo early!—How is this?—You ſeem agitated!

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: Oh Mr. Walſingham!—I know not how—I dare not—but you are Colonel Beauchamp's friend.

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: He has none more ſincere.

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: A dreadful report is circulating within—a quarrel this morning—a duel—I heard the ſtory but imperfectly, but heard enough to alarm me for Beauchamp's ſafety. For pity's ſake, ſir, haſten to him—and ſhould you find this report well founded—

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: I will ſtrain every nerve to prevent the conſequences. But what antagoniſt—?

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: Lord Liſtleſs was named.

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: Lord Liſtleſs! Oh! to my certain knowledge he is otherwiſe engaged at preſent, and has too much reſpect for his own ſafety to endanger any other perſon's. However, I'll go immediately in ſearch of Beauchamp.—So farewell, my dear young lady! make yourſelf eaſy, and depend on my care. Exit.

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: I cannot rejoin the unfeeling crowd within! I'll to my chamber, and if poſſible to reſt. Ah! no—there is now no reſt for me!—Repoſe never viſits my eye-lids till they cloſe wearied with weeping: The ſounds which lull me to ſleep are the groans of a forſaken father, and the ſpirit of dreams ſtill repeats to me his parting curſe! Oh that my next ſlumbers might be the ſlumbers of the grave! Oh that my eyes could for ever ſhut out light, ſince my heart is cloſed againſt peace for ever!

lg.l: COLD winter frowns, but ſoon again
Shall lovely ſpring appear:
The ſun is ſet, but ſoon again
His glorious head ſhall rear:
Night veils the ſkies, but ſoon ſhall day
Once more illume the plain;
But never can a guilty heart
Be ſoothed to peace again.
Oh! ſad is my ſoul!
All my nights are paſs'd in tears!
I think upon my father's houſe,
And all that home endears;
Think, how that father lov'd me well,
But all his love was vain;
I broke his heart, and never ſhall
Mine own know peace again.

div.head: SCENE IV.—A magnificent Apartment at Modiſh's, illuminated.
div.stage: MODISH, TRIFLE, Lady HUBBUB, Mrs. BLAB-ALL, &c. diſcovered—Card Tables, &c.—Ladies and Gentlemen playing at them.

sp.speaker: Lady HUB.
sp.p: Well I never heard any thing ſo ſtrange! Poor Lady Clara, I'm ſure I pity her exceſſively, though I can't but own that ſhe deſerves it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BLAB.
sp.p: Richly, Lady Hubbub, richly, And, for my part, I ſhan't be ſorry to ſee her pride have a fall; which muſt be the caſe ſhortly, for they ſay Mr. Rivers has poſitively refuſed to advance Modiſh a ſingle guinea.

sp.speaker: TRIFLE.
sp.p: Nay it's even whiſpered there are three executions in the houſe at this moment.

sp.speaker: Lady HUB.
sp.p: Oh, as for that, ſince I have known it, this houſe has never been without an execution in it for three days together.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BLAB.
sp.p: Very true, and therefore I wonder that Modiſh ſhould have neglected to provide himſelf with a rotten borough; for he ought to have known, that as he couldn't pay his debts, he had but one alternative, and muſt certainly get into priſon unleſs he got into parliament.

sp.speaker: Lady HUB.
sp.p: Oh! here's Lady Clara!

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA
sp.p: [as entering.] How d'ye do? Charmed to ſee you! Been here long? You there, Trifle!—Ah, Lady Hubbub.

sp.speaker: Lady HUB.
sp.p: Oh my dear Lady Clara!

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Lady HUB.
sp.p: Mr. Rivers—I'm • o concerned for you!—

sp.speaker: Mrs. BLAB.
sp.p: I could cry with vexation!

sp.speaker: Lady HUB.
sp.p: To loſe ſuch a fortune by a trick my dear creature, it grieves me to the heart!

sp.speaker: Mrs. BLAB.
sp.p: And I'm told you muſt part with your beautiful ſet of cream coloured ponies?—Lord! Lord! you've no idea how that diſtreſſes me!

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: Now let me die but you're both of you very kind; and it quite delights me that I'm able to relieve you from ſuch exceſſive affliction. Whatever you may have heard to the contrary, Mr. Rivers and Modiſh are on the beſt terms poſſible, and I hope in a few minutes to have the pleaſure of making him known to you. [Aſide] Spiteful toads!

sp.speaker: Lady HUB.
sp.p:
No really! Lord, I'm prodigious
glad to hear it! [Aſide] I wiſh you were both at the bottom of the Thames!

sp.speaker: Mrs. BLAB.
sp.p: Delighted, my dear Lady Clara! Quite delighted, I proteſt!— [Aſide] Another birth-day ſuit to cut out mine, I'd lay my life on't.

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA,
sp.p: [aſide] —Well, of all earthly torments, the ſympathy of one's friends is certainly the greateſt.—Ha! Miſs Chatterall!—Heavens! What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Miſs CHAT.
sp.p: Oh Lady Clara! Oh Lady Hubbub!—I ſhall faint, Lady Hubbub I ſhall certainly faint.

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: Faint! Why, what has alarmed you?

sp.speaker: MOD.
sp.p: Aye, aye!—All things in order; tell your ſtory firſt, and faint afterwards.

sp.speaker: Miſs CHAT.
sp.p: Oh! your brother, Lady Clara! your vile brother!—I can't ſpeak for paſſion!

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: What has he done?

sp.speaker: Miſs CHAT.
sp.p: What indeed? Why he has—he has— [burſting into tears] —he has carried me off in a ſedan chair! So he has!—How monſtrous! wasn't it?

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: Carried you off!—Mercy, why ſhould he do that?

sp.speaker: MOD.
sp.p: Aye, why indeed?—Oh! I don't believe a word on't.

sp.speaker: Miſs CHAT.
sp.p: Not believe it?—Oh Gemini! but it's very true though; and what's more, ſir, what's more, I'm almoſt morally certain you're one of his accomplices!

sp.speaker: MOD.
sp.p: I?—Oh fye, Miſs Chatterall, fye!

sp.speaker: ALL.
sp.p: Oh! fye, fye, fye!

sp.speaker: Miſs CHAT.
sp.p: Fye, indeed! Fye? Oh that ever I ſhould live to be fyed!—Lady Clara, as I hope to be married, was carried by force to your brother's houſe this evening; and when he firſt handed me out of the ſedan, to give the devil his due, I muſt ſay he was civil enough; but as ſoon as he ſaw that I was I, and nobody but myſelf, he yawned in my face, ſaid I was a great bore, put me into the chair, bade the men box me up tight, and, without ſaying another ſyllable, ſent me back again! How diſagreeable, wasn't it?— [crying bitterly.] —Never, no ſurely never before was ſuch an inſult offered to virtue, delicacy, and the firſt couſin of an Iriſh Peer!—But I'll be revenged! I'll to my lawyer's, and have an action for burglary brought againſt him without delay; and if the law won't do me right, I warrant my Iriſh uncle Sir Blarney O'Blunderbuſs will!—Oh he'll come to my aſſiſtance, good ſoul, at the firſt word; will inſiſt on his Lordſhip's repairing by marriage the injury done my reputation; and when I once find myſelf his wife—oh what a miſerable wretch I'll make him! Exit.

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA
sp.p: [laughing.] —But what can all this mean? Ha! Modiſh, I ſee Rivers advancing.

sp.speaker: MOD.
sp.p: [aſide.] I tremble to meet him; I feel how ungratefully I have treated him; and my only conſolation is, that I felt it before I knew how much my ingratitude had coſt me.

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: So here he comes—Now, ladies—now, ladies, you ſhall ſee—

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: [to RIVERS] —Remember your promiſe—Gentleneſs!

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Oh, never fear!

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA
sp.p: [to Mrs. Ormond]. And here you are at laſt? My dear creature, you've no notion how you've agitated me; I've expected you this half hour, and was almoſt afraid that ſome accident had happened—and Mr. Rivers too, I declare!—My dear ſir, I can ſcarcely thank you for this viſit for laughing when I think of the ridiculous affair of this morning: well I never was ſo quizzed in my life; but you muſt certainly have a world of humour!

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: [drily.] Um, aye, it was ridiculous enough; but yet the beſt part of the joke is ſtill to come.

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: Is it? Dear, I'm prodigiouſly glad to hear it, for it has entertained me ſo, you have no idea—

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Pardon me, I can conceive it perfectly.

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: Impoſſible, quite impoſſible! And indeed I called at your houſe this evening for the ſole purpoſe of ſaying how extremely—

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: My houſe!—Mrs. Ormond's you mean. Your Ladyſhip forgets—I live at the Three Blue Poſts in Little Britain.

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! very true; and Modiſh muſt pay his reſpects to you at the Three Blue Poſts, I ſuppoſe?

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: May I expect ſo much condeſcenſion from Mr. Modiſh?

sp.speaker: MOD.
sp.p:
Mr. Rivers, I will not aggravate my fault by attempting to excuſe it; I am heartily aſhamed of my behaviour this morning, and ſee it
myſelf in ſuch offenſive colours, that I cannot hope by any preſent ſubmiſſions to obtain your pardon.

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Give me your hand, ſir; the beſt thing is certainly not to commit a fault, but the next beſt is to be ſorry for it when committed.—And yet, when you reflect on Lady Clara's very flattering reception of me this morning, you cannot poſſibly found any expectations on my aſſiſtance, though, Heaven knows, at this very moment you ſtand wofully in need of it.

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: At this moment?

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Certainly; for in the firſt place there is an execution in the houſe.

sp.speaker: TRIFLE.
sp.p: Good night, Modiſh. Exit.

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: There goes one! [aſide.] —Then, Modiſh, Squeez'em the uſurer has taken out a writ againſt you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BLAB.
sp.p: Your ſervant, Lady Clara.

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: [aſide] There go two!—So that you will certainly go to priſon to-morrow, unleſs you can borrow a conſiderable ſum among your acquaintance—

sp.speaker: Lady HUB.
sp.p: Call Lady Hubbub's ſervants, if you pleaſe, ſir. Exit.

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: [aſide.] There goes a third!—And can get two of your friends to ſtand bail for you.

sp.speaker: ALL.
sp.p: Mr. Modiſh, we wiſh you a very good night! Exeunt.

div.stage: Manent RIVERS, MODISH, Lady CLARA, and Mrs. ORMOND.

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Bravo, bravo! There goes the whole covey!

sp.speaker: MOD.
sp.p: Narrow-hearted raſcals!

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: What, all gone!—Lord bleſs me!—What, all!—

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Aye, aye, Lady Clara, the coaſt is clear; and what otherwiſe could you expect? what elſe than—

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: Huſh! huſh! my dear ſir! Surely they are already ſufficiently mortified, and to puniſh them farther would be both cruel and unneceſſary—Suffer me then to plead for my brother—and—

sp.speaker: MOD.
sp.p: Emily, you muſt plead in vain: Lady Clara's imprudence has been too groſs, my ingratitude too culpable to—

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: May be ſo, George; but you may as well confine your reproaches to your own breaſt, ſince your ſiſter has already carried the point for you, and I have promiſed to diſcharge your debts.

sp.speaker: MOD. and Lady CLARA.
sp.p: Dear ſir, in what manner—

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Nay, no thanks, or, if you needs muſt pay them, offer them to Emily; they are her due, and I can tell you, George—

div.stage: Enter JOHN, delivers a Letter to Mrs. ORMOND, and exit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: [after reading it.] Good Heavens!

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Emily, what has alarmed you? You change colour!

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: Something has happened which—Might I requeſt a few moments private converſation with you?

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p:
Oh! pray conſider yourſelf at
home, my dear—we leave you. [To Modiſh] Will you come, Love?

sp.speaker: MOD.
sp.p: Come, my life?—To be ſure I will.

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: [looking after them.] Fudge!—And now Emily, what diſmal tale have you to relate?

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: One, my dear ſir, which intereſts me nearly. Soon after your leaving me this morning, I owed my reſcue from the groſſeſt impertinence to an officer, who unluckily was indebted for a large ſum to the coxcomb by whom I was inſulted. This note informs me, that, in conſequence of having afforded me his protection, he has been arreſted, and is now confined at the ſuit of Lord Liſtleſs.

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Confined? He ſhall not be ſo long. England needs ſuch men, nor ſhall ſhe be deprived of them, while I can help it.—What does your friend owe?—

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: Not leſs than 3000l.

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: A large ſum! But no matter! Set your heart at reſt, Emily; the debt ſhall be diſcharged.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: My dear ſir!—

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Pſha! dear nonſenſe! And his name?—

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: You will be ſurpriſed to hear, that my friend is no other than Colonel Beauchamp.

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: [ſtarting.] Beauchamp!—

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p:
Even he; and his conduct to me this morning muſt convince you, that, if he has faults, he is not without virtues—but I haſten with theſe good tidings to Miſs Mandeville.—Oh Mr. Rivers! believe me I feel well, how trifling a gift is the wealth which you heap upon me, compared
to the advantages which my ſon will reap from your acquaintance; much from your precepts, but more from your example. Exit.

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p:
[
• e • us.] My embarraſſments increaſe every hour—Why, why muſt Beauchamp have faults to none but me?—What courſe ſhall I purſue?—Suppoſe—Yes! I'll diſcharge his debts under a feigned name, and, when he's at liberty, challenge him in my own; the firſt to reward his merits, the ſecond to avenge my wrongs! It ſhall be ſo—and if I fall to-morrow—then may my poor Zorayda find Heaven more merciful than ſhe found her father!—May God forgive her, but I never can! Exit.

div.head: SCENE I.—Lady CLARA's.
div.stage: ZORAYDA diſcovered ſeated on a Sofa, and leaning her Head on Mrs. ORMOND's Shoulder. Lady CLARA is ſtanding near her.

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: NAY, ſweet Zorayda, why this deſpair? Probably ere this, the cauſe of yoor diſtreſs has ceaſed, and Beauchamp is at liberty.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: Calm your ſpirits, deareſt girl! Believe me this exceſs of grief is childiſh, when every thing bids you hope—

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: Hope!—Mine is fled for ever!—My father, madam, my father!—I planted his path with thorns; I ſhould have ſtrewn it with •• ſes:—he warmed me in his boſom; the ſnake ſtung him to the heart:—he loved me; I abandoned him:—he curſed me, and I dare not hope!

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: Oh bluſh, Zorayda! when thus ſinking beneath misfortune—

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: Not beneath misfortune; 'tis beneath the burthen of my faults I ſink. Oh! well may innocence ſee the lightning flaſh without alarm; well may virtue lift her head undaunted above the billows.—But when with ſufferings comes the conſciouſneſs of their being deſerved, oh they are inſupportable, and I faint beneath the weight of mine!—

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p:
Dear, unhappy girl!—Would to
Heaven Rivers were returned!—Pray, Lady Clara, did Zorayda ſee him this morning?

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: No: I have ſince heard that by ſome unaccountable miſtake he was conducted to Miſs Chatterall inſtead of her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: Miſs Chatterall? Oh! then the caſe is clear. Know then, my Zorayda— [Knocking without.]

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: Hark! a carriage ſtops—It muſt be Mr. Rivers.

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: [ſtarting from the ſopha.] Oh! I fear!—I fear!—

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: You grow pale; retire, my love, and compoſe yourſelf.

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: But Beauchamp—

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: As ſoon as I have learnt the reſult of Rivers's viſit, I will haſten to let you know it.

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: And delay not, pray delay not!—Oh father, father! could you know what I feel at this moment, you would own, that, great as my faults have been, they are equalled by my ſufferings!

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: Poor Zorayda!—Perhaps Mr. Rivers's interceſſion may induce her father—

div.stage: Re-enter ZORAYDA haſtily through the Folding-Doors.

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: Save me, madam!—Oh ſave me! ſave me!—

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: What alarms you?—Save you from whom?

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: My father! Oh my father! I ſaw him from the window by the flambeau's light!—Even now he entered the houſe.

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA and Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: How! Your father!

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: [without.] Very well—I'll go up ſtairs.

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: Hark! hark! hark! 'Tis his voice, 'tis his voice!—Oh! where ſhall I hide me, whither fly to avoid his reſentment?

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: I know not what—Yet ſurely—Fear nothings my love; all ſhall yet be well—leave it to me; compoſe your ſpirits—retire, and wait till I rejoin you—Lady Clara!—

sp.speaker: Lady CLARA.
sp.p: I will take care of her—Come, dear Zorayda!—

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: I obey; but, oh how cruel is it to ſhudder at his approach, whoſe ſight is dearer to me than my own, and baniſh myſelf from his preſence, whoſe embrace I would die to obtain!

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: Yes, I muſt try it; Rivers muſt have his daughter again.

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: So that buſineſs is done—There, Emily, ſet your heart at reſt; your champion is free.—But hey! the deuce! you ſeem if poſſible ſtill more diſturbed than when I left you!—I hope you've not met with more impertinent peers and generous protectors?

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: Not exactly; the cauſe of my preſent emotion rather concerns my former protector.

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: What! Beauchamp again?

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: No, the buſineſs now regards Beauchamp's miſtreſs; but I find you've made a terrible miſtake.—The lady you ſaw here this evening was a woman of the very ſtricteſt virtue.

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p:
Zounds! what a blunder! Why the poor
creature muſt have thought me mad, for I propoſed packing her off to India without ceremony. But where then is the real Miſs Mandeville? Does ſhe not reſide with Lady Clara?

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: She does, and you may now, my dear ſir, execute the plan which—

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Nay, I've blundered in the outſet of it ſo confoundedly, that I wiſh ſome other perſon—

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: No one can undertake this buſineſs ſo properly as yourſelf.—I've perſuaded her that your interceſſion with her father—

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Mine? Why I don't know him even by ſight!

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: True—but your conſequence—your Indian connections—In ſhort, ſee her; talk to her; adviſe her:—Shew her the impropriety of continuing with Beauchamp, paint to her what her father muſt ſuffer at her abſence, and comfort her with the hope of obtaining his pardon:—But be gentle with her, I intreat you; moderate your naturally impetuous temper; and beware not to heap freſh anguiſh on an heart, whoſe wounds are already deep—whoſe ſufferings are already exquiſite!

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Poor Emily! She little thinks that the man from whoſe friendſhip ſhe hopes ſo much, in a few hours will either be expiring himſelf, or a fugitive from England, ſtained with the blood of Beauchamp! My will, however, ſecures her in affluence, and after that—

div.stage: Enter Mrs. ORMOND and ZORAYDA veiled, through the Folding-Doors.

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: But ſee, ſhe comes with her protegée—Ha! veiled, I ſee!

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: [aſide to Zorayda.] Nay, deareſt girl, why thus terrified? Doubt it not, all will turn out well.

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: [aſide to Mrs. Ormond.] Yes, yes! 'tis he!—How I tremble at his preſence!

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM
sp.p: In vain have I endeavoured, my dear ſir, to convince Miſs Mandeville t • at ſhe dreads, without reaſon, the ſeverity of your ſt • ctures. I aſſure her that you will ſpeak to her....

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Moſt ſoothingly! moſt kindly! Even as a father would ſpeak to his daughter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p:
[
• agerly.] Right! exactly right! Remember your promiſe—Speak to her as an indulgent father would to his daughter, his beloved and repentant daughter. I leave you with her. My dear girl....

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: [embracing her] Oh, madam!

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: [aſide] Would it were over! Yet what ſhould I dread? I know well the excellence of his nature; and hard indeed muſt that heart be which can liſten unmoved to the pleading of ſuch a penitent! Exit.

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: [after a pauſe] I...I...preſume, Miſs Mandeville, you are aware how delicate a taſk Mrs. Ormond has impoſed on me. [Zorayda bows.] So delicate, in truth, that no ſentiment could induce my undertaking it leſs ſtrong than gratitude for your generous intentions towards myſelf, and the intereſt which Emily's account of you at firſt inſpired me with, and which your own appearance could not fail to increaſe.

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: [aſide] Oh that dear voice! Yet how terrible it ſounds!

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p:
I will not dwell upon the worth of public opinion, the bleſſings of ſelf-ſatisfaction, the torments of preſent ſhame and of future remorſe; I
know full well how light theſe conſiderations weigh againſt love when a young hand holds the balance. 'Twas your heart which led you aſtray; to your heart then will I make my appeal; and, if it be not marble, I ſhall not make my appeal in vain. Miſs Mandeville, I will ſpeak of your father—will explain how heavy is a father's curſe—will paint how dreadful is a father's anguiſh!—Well can I deſcribe that anguiſh! I have felt it, feel it ſtill! I once had a daughter—!

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: [aſide] His voice falters!

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: This daughter....Oh! how I loved her, words cannot ſay, thought cannot meaſure!—This daughter ſacrificed me for a villain, fled from my paternal roof, and....her flight has broken my heart—her ingratitude has dug my grave!

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: [aſide] How I ſuffer!—Oh my God!

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: [recovering himſelf] Young Lady, my daughter's ſeducer was Beauchamp! He has deſerted her; ſo, doubt it not, will he deſert you. My execration is upon her! Oh! let not your father's fall upon you as heavy. Haſte to him ere it be too late! Wait not till his reſentment becomes rooted—till his reſolve becomes immutable—'till he ſheds ſuch burning tears as I now ſhed—'till he ſuffers ſuch bitter pangs as I now ſuffer—'till he curſes as I now curſe....

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: [throwing aſide her veil, and ſinking on her knees] Spare me! ſpare me!

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Zorayda!— [after a pauſe] Away!

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: Pardon! pardon!

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Leave me, girl!

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p:
While I have life, never again! Never; no, not even though you ſtill frown on me! Nay, ſtruggle not!—Father, I am a poor deſperate diſtracted creature! Still ſhall my lips, till ſealed by
death, cry to you for mercy—ſtill will I thus claſp my father's hand, till he cuts off mine, or elſe forgives me!

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Zorayda! Girl!.....Hence, fooliſh tears!

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: I hope not for kindneſs, I ſue but for pardon—I aſk not to live happy in your love, I plead but to die ſoothed by your forgiveneſs.—Still • oath my fault, frown on me ſtill, daſh me on the earth, trample me in the duſt, kill me—but forgive me!

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Her voice—her tears—I can ſupport them no longer.

div.stage: [Breaks from her, and haſtens to the door.]

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: [wringing her hands in deſpair] Cruel! cruel! My God! my God!—Oh! were my mother but alive!

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: [ſtarting.] Her mother!

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: Ah! he ſtops. She lives then! lives too in his heart!—Oh! plead thou for me, ſainted ſpirit! plead thou too, in former ſorrows my greateſt comfort, in preſent ſufferings my only hope!— [Taking a picture from her boſom] Look on it, my father! 'tis the portrait of your wife, of your adored Zorayda!—Look on theſe eyes—you have ſo often ſaid they were like mine. Be moved by my voice—you have ſo often ſaid it reminded you of my mother's!—'Tis ſhe who thus ſinks at your feet—'tis ſhe who now cries to you, Pardon your erring, your repentant child!—Father, I ſtand on the brink of ruin: already the ground gives way beneath my feet—yet a moment, and I am loſt!—Save me! Father, ſave me! If not for my ſake, if not for your own, oh father, father! ſave me for my mother's ſake!

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: [Looking alternately at the portrait and her.] Zorayda—Zorayda!—My child! my child!

div.stage: Enter MODISH, Lady CLARA, and Mrs. ORMOND.

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM
sp.p: He yields, and we triumph.

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: [recovering himſelf.] Yet mark me, Zorayda—Beauchamp....

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: Alas!

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Never muſt you meet again; to-morrow either ſees him ſtained with my blood, or this hand muſt....

sp.speaker: ALL.
sp.p: How! Beauchamp?

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Aſtoniſhment!— [To Zorayda ſternly] Follow me!

sp.speaker: BEAU.
sp.p: Stay, Mr. Rivers; hear me for one moment.

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Hear you? Amazing confidence!—What? hear you extenuate your crime? hear you ſay that....

sp.speaker: BEAU.
sp.p: That I am guilty, that miſery ought to be my lot; but that, if my lot be miſery, it muſt alſo be Zorayda's. On your affection for her I throw myſelf Great have been my faults, great have been Zorayda's injuries—yet, if ſuffered to repair them....

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Repair them! and your wife....

sp.speaker: BEAU.
sp.p:
Her death has been long reported; this letter, juſt received, aſcertains the fact. My hand is free, and from the firſt moment I beheld her that hand was deſtined to your daughter. I feel
how little I deſerve her—feel the whole weight of my offence, and loath myſelf for its commiſſion:—but my puniſhment would be Zorayda's—but Zorayda's fate is interwoven with mine. Be this my plea, when thus I kneel before you, imploring permiſſion to expiate my faults to your daughter and yourſelf by affection for my wife and unremitting attention to her father.

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: Nor imagine, ſir, that your wealth influences this propoſal. Continue ſtill your diſpoſitions in Mrs. Ormond's favour; my fortune is ample, it has long been deſtined to Beauchamp, and the day which makes him your ſon makes him my heir.

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: [heſitating.] I know not...I ought not...

sp.speaker: Mrs. ORM.
sp.p: Dear ſir, if my entreaties....

sp.speaker: WAL.
sp.p: If my advice....

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: [embracing him.] Dear, dear father!

sp.speaker: ALL.
sp.p: Pardon! pardon!

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: I am vanquiſhed! Riſe, riſe my ſon, and receive from me Zorayda!

sp.speaker: BEAU.
sp.p: My love! my wife! Oh, teach me to thank your father for ſo invaluable a gift!

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: Edward to be yours, and with his approbation!....Dear, dear ſir, is not all this a dream? Am I indeed again your Zorayda? Is your affection indeed mine again?

sp.speaker: RIV.
sp.p: Your's it was ever; and ſurely, had I loved you leſs, I had been appeaſed more eaſily. Many a pang, my child, has your abſence coſt me; but the pleaſure of this moment overpays them all. Sweet, oh! ſweet are a father's tears ſhed on the boſom of a repentant child. Hear this, ye flinty-hearted—hear it, and pardon!—Yet how is this? when every other face wears a ſmile, why hangs a cloud on the brow of my Zorayda?

sp.speaker: ZOR.
sp.p: Ah, my father! 'tis a cloud which muſt never be removed; for, 'tis the gloom of ſelf-reproach!—I have erred, and been forgiven; but am I therefore leſs culpable?—Your indulgence has been great; but is my fault therefore leſs enormous? Oh, no, no, no! The calm of innocence has for ever left me, the courage of conſcious virtue muſt be mine no more! Still muſt the memory of errors paſt torment me, and embitter every future joy:—ſtill muſt I bluſh to read ſcorn in the world's eye, ſuſpicion in my huſband's:—and ſtill muſt feel this painful truth moſt keenly, that ſhe who once deviates from the paths of virtue, though ſhe may obtain the forgiveneſs of others, never can obtain her own!

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.stage: The Ghoſt of QUEEN ELIZABETH riſes in a Flaſh of Fire.

lg.l: Stare not, fair dames, nor criticize my dreſs;
You ſee before you jolly old Queen Beſs,
Who from the land of roaſting, boiling, ſtewing,
Is come to ſee what you above are doing!
Below, where ſome ſlight peccadilloes ſent me,
Long did a wiſh, a fooliſh wiſh torment me,
For ſome few days in Britain to revive,
And view that land once more, I lov'd ſo well alive:—
This wiſh ſo teas'd me, morn, night, noon, and eve,
That I reſolv'd to aſk old Pluto's leave;
And though I knew to gain the point was hard,
Boldly diſpatch'd Lord Burleigh with this card.
"Queen Beſs's comp'ts to Pluto—begs to ſay
"She hopes, this card will find him well to-day;
"And ſhould her viſit now convenient be,
"Means to drink ſulphur with his majeſty.
For in our lower realms the truth to utter,
Sulphur means tea, and brimſtone bread and butter.
Well, he receiv'd me, and (my ſulphur ſipp'd,)
"Dear Sir," quoth I—"I'm nervous, ſick, and hipp'd,
"Beſides have frightful dreams, and truth to ſpeak,
"Scarce eat a chicken's pinion in a week.
"Shock'd at my ſickly plight and ſtrange condition,
"I've aſk'd advice of maint and maint phyſician;
"And having heard them with one voice declare,
"Nothing can cure me but a change of air,
"'Tis my deſign, for health and for diverſion,
"To Albion's Iſle to make a ſhort excurſion—
At this old Pluto look'd extremely glum,
Firſt ſcratch'd his head, then frown'd, and bit his thumb;
At length the buſineſs ſifted to the dregs,
Thus ſpoke the king with the flame-coloured legs:
"Go, Beſs," he anſwer'd ('twas not o'er civil
To crop my name, but 'tis an ill-bred Divle!)
"Go, Beſs," he anſwered; "you've my full permiſſion
"To viſit London on this one condition.
"To-night at Drury, (ſo the papers tell)
"Is play'd a Comédie that's toute nouvelle"—
"I to this piece your new exiſtence tie,
"And, as it lives or dies, you live or die.
"Should the dread ordeal with ſucceſs be paſs'd,
"Your ſecond life ſhall for the ſeaſon laſt;
"But, ſhould it fail, inſtant (I'd have you know it)
"Here you return, and with you....bring the poet."
I took his offer, pack'd up hoods and ruffs,
Strait bodice, farthingales, and little muffs;
And leaſt old Dis ſhould take his promiſe back,
Through yon trap-door reach'd Drury in a crack.
Now then I come before the Public's throne,
To plead the author's cauſe, and eke my own.
Think with what terrors muſt my boſom tremble,
Since that the piece is bad I can't diſſemble:
Yet, weary with my journey, faint with fright;
Pray don't oblige me to ſet out to-night;
Rather with kind applauſe prolong my ſtay,
And for a few ſhort nights ſupport the play.
But, ſhould my prayers prove vain, ſhould the piece fail,
The plot thought dull,—the humour coarſe and ſtale,
Beſs out of ſorts, and Poet out of feather,
Are damn'd alike, and jog down ſtairs together.
